Homage to the Bodhisattva Ä€Å›aya-rÄja
Homage to the Bodhisattva Power of Reliance. I take refuge in the bodhisattvas, mahÄsattvas, immeasurable and boundless in the worlds of the ten directions, such as these.
I respectfully pay homage to the Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and all the sages.
Having paid homage to the Three Jewels, I will next repent.
Disciples!
Having together repented the three karmic actions of the body, we should now in order repent the four evil karmic actions of speech.
The sÅ«tras say:

The sin of verbal karmic action can cause sentient beings to fall into the hells and hungry ghosts to suffer. If in the animal realm, they will receive the form of an owl, a hawk, or a vulture. Those who hear its voice will hate it.
If reborn among humans, their breath will always smell bad. People will not believe or accept their words. Their relatives will not be harmonious, and they will always enjoy fighting.
Since verbal karmic action has such evil consequences, therefore, disciples!
Today with utmost sincerity I take refuge in the Buddha.

Homage to the Buddha of the Constellations in the East, Homage to the Buddha of the Moonlight in the South, Homage to the Buddha of Boundless Vision in the West, Homage to the Buddha of the Unconquerable King in the North, Homage to the Buddha of the Great Incense King in the Southeast, Homage to the Buddha of Non-Action Contemplation in the Southwest, Homage to the Buddha of Joyful Purity in the Northwest, Homage to the Buddha of Victory in Battle in the Northeast, Homage to the Buddha of Removing All Delusion and Darkness in the Nadir, Homage to the Buddha of the King of Good Certainty in the Zenith. We take refuge in the Three Jewels in the ten directions and throughout the realm of space.
Disciples!

From beginningless time until today, we have lied, spoken divisively, harshly, and frivolously; we have transmitted emptiness as existence and existence as emptiness; we have said we have seen what we have not seen and have not seen what we have seen; we have said we have heard what we have not heard and have not heard what we have heard; we have said we know what we do not know and do not know what we know; we have deceived the sages and the wise, with our words and actions contradicting each other;

Praising oneself and disparaging others, claiming to have attained superhuman abilities, saying one has attained the four dhyÄnas, the four formless concentrations, the sixteen aspects of the practice of mindfulness of breathing, the fruit of stream-entry up to arhatship, saying one has attained the stage of a pratyekabuddha or an irreversible bodhisattva, saying gods, dragons, ghosts, spirits, whirlwinds, and earth-dwelling ghosts all come to one, answering their questions, displaying the extraordinary to confuse the assembly, seeking worldly fame and profit.
Such offenses are immeasurable and boundless. Today, we confess and repent of them, taking refuge and repenting.
Furthermore, disciples!

From beginningless time until today, we have slandered and incited discord, fanning the flames between others, using divisive speech to create divisions, speaking ill of others behind their backs, leading this person to say that about the other, separating others from their relatives, breaking up marriages, and exhausting our tongues in slander.
Speaking of others' strengths and weaknesses, destroying others' good friendships, causing those who are close to become distant, and turning relatives into enemies.

Or with frivolous speech, false words, and inappropriate speech, slandering and defaming rulers and fathers, disparaging teachers and elders, destroying loyal and good people, burying those superior to oneself, communicating between two countries, fanning discord between them, floating flowers and empty cleverness, always speaking falsely, with words and thoughts not matching, the path not being one, praising and extolling to the face, then scolding and criticizing behind the back, praising and reciting heretical scriptures and spreading heretical evil teachings.
Or with harsh speech, cursing and using coarse and violent language, calling out to heaven and pointing to the earth, dragging in ghosts and spirits.

Like this, the various offenses produced by oral karma are immeasurable and boundless. Today, with utmost sincerity, I take refuge and repent before the Buddhas, the supreme Dharma, and the noble Sangha in the ten directions.

May the disciples, by inheriting the merits produced from repenting of the offenses of oral karma and so forth, wish to be endowed with the eight sounds, the four unobstructed eloquences, and always speak words of harmony, benefit, and interest, with a voice that is pure and elegant, and all are happy to hear it, skillfully understanding the languages and customs of sentient beings.
If there is something to be said, it should be timely and appropriate, enabling the listeners to gain understanding and enter the sagely, opening the eye of wisdom.
The Sutra of the Questions and Answers of the Bodhisattva of the Lotus Treasure on Karmic Retribution, Scroll 1. Baota previously entered a hell of disputations.
Why is it called the hell of disputations?
The hell is eighty yojanas long and wide, surrounded by iron walls and covered with a net above. There are iron spikes in it, also as described above.

There are iron hooks in it that hook the tongues of the offenders. There are also iron axes that come to chop their tongues, cutting them off inch by inch. There are also molten bronze that is poured into their mouths and comes out from their backs. They suffer countless punishments in a single day and night, dying and being revived ten thousand times, dying and being revived a thousand times.
In the west gate, there are six thousand monks who enter into it. The offenders wail and are unwilling to enter.

The horse-headed rÄká¹£asa grabbed an iron trident, thrusting it into the chest and coming out through the back, entering and exiting within. Iron birds flew high in the sky, swooping down and entering.

When the sinners raised their heads, [the trident] entered through their mouths and came out from the soles of their feet. There were also pythons entering their eyes, and fire burning within their bodies.
Baodala asked:
What karma did these monks create that they have come into this place to receive such punishment?
The rÄká¹£asa replied:

These monks received the Buddha's precepts but did not protect them for the future. They said, 'We are Dharma teachers of the Great Vehicle,' but it was like in the dark of night. Each said, 'I have attained the Buddha's teachings and deeply understand the Buddha's meaning,' and then explained it to others.
Leading their followers, they roamed among the people, sometimes receiving the offerings of faith and support from kings. Their inner thoughts were as lofty as mountains and seas.
They were like withered trees with only their bark, their inner core rotten and useless.
These monks were also like this.
Because of this cause and condition, they fall into this hell. After leaving hell, if they are reborn among humans, they are deaf, blind, mute, and do not hear the true Dharma.
When Baodai heard this, he wept sorrowfully and left.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The Buddha's Name Sutra, Scroll 23
